title: surge-39-struggling-39-families-sees-demand-kids-39-lunch-club-soar
story: More than  children took part in this summerrsquos club compared to just  when it began in .And Universal Credit has been blamed for the dramatic increase in families who need help providing their children with a healthy meal, during the holidays.Sandra King, from Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership, who help fund the club, which runs in Prestonpans and Tranent, said there was no doubt the impact of East Lothian being used to pilot the roll-out of Universal Credit was being witnessed.She said: ldquoIt is like being back in the Seventies: the number of families who are struggling and need support is high and the Universal Credit pilot in East Lothian has definitely had an impact.The outward appearance of East Lothian as an affluent county was misleading, she added, with families in all of its town and communities struggling.She said: ldquoEven in places like North Berwick we are seeing families affected. It is an issue which touches every community.The club, which is run by Fundamental Foods, began in Prestonpans after local headteacher Sheila Laing highlighted the struggle some families faced and has extended to a second base in Tranent.In Prestonpans, they moved the club into Preston Tower Primary School this year from the Pennypit Pagoda because they needed more space.In Tranent, it operates at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School.Both the Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership and Farsquoside Area Partnership help fund the holiday club with money given to them by East Lothian Council as part of their food poverty strategy.The local authority set up a short-le working group to look at how to tackle food poverty following the establishment of East Lothian Poverty Commission in .The group looked specically at ways to help children and young people who need support for ldquoholiday and every day hunger.One of their key actions is to support and develop breakfast, after school and summer lunch clubs in schools.As well as providing daily activities and healthy meals for youngsters, the club in Prestonpans and Tranent has a pantry stocked with food and available for everyone to help themselves to items they need as they enter and leave the club.Local branches of Tesco, Aldi and the Co-op regularly supply the club with leftover food and  staff and volunteers run the club, at both its centres, including an additional support needs specialist.Ruth Davie, from Fundamental Foods which is part of the Prestonpans-based Pennypit Trust, said children come from all over the Preston Seton Gosford and neighbouring Farsquoside wards to the club. Most are referred.She said local knowledge allows them to identy families who need extra help through the community.Ruth said: ldquoIt is really important children can access healthy food and can be dficult for parents during school holidays.ldquoWe have a number of families with a lot of children and provide a service for children aged three to . Some of the older children come back and volunteer as well.As well as food, the club provides free toiletries and took the youngsters on trips over the holidays to places such as East Links Family Park, Dunbar.And free haircuts were provided by Cockenzie-based Unique salon.This week the club has been replaced with a unorm swap shop as school s next week.

title: thousands-spent-musselburgh-racecourse-buildings
story: The independent report on the condition of buildings at the historic course found the majority of it was in a satisfactory condition.However, it was critical of areas used by staff, which were in some parts described as being in a ldquopoor state.It said the racecourse workshop, which houses both staff from the course and other East Lothian Council amenity services, required an overhaul, calling for flooring which it described as ldquovery dirty to be given a deep clean ndash and the toilet facilities too.It said: ldquoThe electric shower, ceramic WCs and wash hand basins with chrome taps are in a poor condition and are either damagedor require a deep clean.East Lothian Council is currently seeking a third-party operator for the course, which is currently overseen by the Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee .The survey was carried out ahead of the tendering process to ensure the facilities were up to standard.The report acknowledged the age of some of the older buildings on the site but highlighted missing ceiling tiles and grouting work which needed to be fixed.It also urged operators to have a fire risk assessment carried out for the main grandstand to ensure the fire breaks in its roof space are sufficient.The report was one of a number which were presented to MRAC in private at the end of last year.They have now been released to the public under the Freedom of Information Act.It is understood that local tradespeople are being used to carry out the work detailedin the survey, which is expected to cost substantially less than the independent estimate of pound,.Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said: ldquoWork is in progress to maintain standards around ious parts of the racecourse and the expenditure is reasonable for a sporting and leisure facility which welcomes , visitors a year.

title: new-affordable-homes-cockenzie-armed-forces-veterans
story: The development at Osborne Terrace, Cockenzie, is being built to cater specically for disabled veterans and will consist of six two-bedroom flats.The building site was visited by Graeme Dey MSP, minister for parliamentary business and veterans on Tuesday morning.He said: ldquoAs veteransrsquo minister, itrsquos my job to ensure that we provide the right support for the Armed Forces community across Scotland.ldquoThe Scottish Government is fully committed to supporting the Armed Forces, veterans and their families, and to ensuring they are not disadvantaged by their service or the circumstance they find themselves in because of this.ldquoIt was a pleasure to visit Osborne Terrace to see the construction of these new, affordable homes for veterans.ldquoOur Armed Forces community deserves the best possible levels of support when they need it most ndash and this project is a great example of that.Construction started May with completion scheduled for December.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for housing and its the Armed Forces Champion, said: ldquoThe move from service le to civilian le can present challenges for personnel and their families in a wide range of areas.ldquoThis new development is a shining example of working together with partners to provide much-needed housing for veterans with specic needs. Irsquom sure it will make a dference to those who live here and their families. It also builds on the work wersquore already doing to support veterans in general, to whom society as a whole owes a debt.East Lothian Council has also signed an Armed Forces Covenant, which brings together key partners from the council alongside health, education, service and veteransrsquo organisations to create policy and practices that will support armed forces personnel, both serving and retired, and their families.The Scottish Veterans Garden City Associationwill be one of the groups working with the council on this project, as well as being a key player in the Osborne Terrace development.Richard Callander, chairman of the SVGCA said: ldquoSVGCA are delighted to be working in partnership with East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government to provide affordable quality housing for veterans in need.ldquoSVGCA intends to replicate this ground-breaking opportunity Scotland wide and is meeting with other partners but thanks East Lothian Council for being the first local authority to deliver on the scheme.

title: spice-witch-puts-spell-judges-tasty-product
story: The Spice Witch, based in Prestonpans, can now add its Mellow Chilli Jam to the list of Great Taste Awards handed out by the Guild of Fine Foods. The jam is the fth Spice Witch product to win this award.Janice Strachan, founder of Spice Witch, said: ldquoWe are thrilled to have received our fth Great Taste Award in three years, our Mellow Chilli Jam now joins The Spice Witchrsquos winning team comprised of Spiced Cherries, Mango and Chilli Chutney, Hot chilli Jam and Smokey Tomato Relish.ldquoItrsquos wonderful that the Guild of Fine Food recognises the enormous effort that goes into each jar. We are so very grateful to our customers.

title: bell-former-high-kirk-st-andrews-chiming
story: The upgrade project was led by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council which contributed pound, and received pound, from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund to cover the cost of the work at the former B-listed High Kirk of St Andrews, on High Street.The building, which dates back to the th century, has been used as a dolls museum in the past and, now known as the Copernicus Kirk, is the headquarters of space technology company Astrosat.The former church, featuring a central tower with a clock face on each side, was built in  by renowned architect R Thornton Shiells.A new digital mechanism has replaced cogs which operated the clock. The last has not sounded since .Irene Tait, community council chairperson, said: ldquoI am delighted that the three clock faces on the building are now in working order. The job was undertaken by clockmakers Smiths of Derby. It has taken a few months from start to finish and we are very pleased indeed with the work they carried out.ldquoThe clocks will chime from am on the hour until pm for the present. I would point out that the staff at Astrosat have been on hand to help out from a safety angle and when engineers or electricians were required. Astrosat are making a floodlight which will enhance the clocks from behind the structure in the winter months.ldquoThe community council is very pleased with the response from local people who seem to be delighted that a huge part of their Musselburgh history has been maintained. I would like to thank the Common Good Fund Committee, Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council members and Astrosat for all the support receivedFraser Hamilton of Astrosat said: ldquoHidden in plain view in the heart of Musselbugh, Astrosat continues its mission to be the gateway to unlocking the secrets of satellite data and thereby empowering everyday data solutions for a changing tomorrow. This mission extends not only to the heady heights of space data but to our roots and how we can give back to the community, something that started by ing a central and iconic piece of architecture to practical use as a technology hub and serviceable office space.ldquoWith the now re-commissioned clock tower operating successfully, the additional installation of backlighting will ensure that the faces of the clock tower remain visible in the night sky as a beacon at the crossroads to Musselburghrsquos heart.ldquoThe chimes of the bells have been silent for sometime in Musselburgh but, with the support provided by the community council, we are extremely proud to find ourselves as custodians of the hourly chimes.ldquoAs they sound out across Musselburgh, it is another small example of benefits that the space industry can bring to the many people that consider themselves largely disconnected from it.The Musselburgh Common Good Committee is made up of the townrsquos councillors.Chairman Stuart Currie commented: ldquoWersquore delighted to support the refurbishment of this landmark in the town. It is a great tribute to the community council that they identy projects that can be supported by the Common Good Funds that really help improve the town.Councillor John Willamson said: ldquoItrsquos good to see the clocks working again after such a long period when they were out of action. Well done to the community council for taking the lead on this long overdue project.And Councillor Katie Mackie added: ldquoIt is great to see these clocks back in action thanks to the combined efforts of the community council and the Musselburgh Common Good Fund.While Councillor Andy Forrest said: ldquoI welcome the work done by the community council to refurbish the clock at the church. It was also heartening to see local business Astrosat work with the community council regarding health and safety issues once the work was completed.

title: charity-39-blown-away-generosity-39-mum-of-two-39-s-friends
story: The fundraiser, set up through Facebook, is in tribute to Leigh, of Prestonpans, who passed away aged  from secondary breast cancer at the end of last month. She was mother to Aaronand Maxwelland we of Euan.The money raised will go to charity Make nds Count which works to raise awareness and funds for research into secondary breast cancer.Euan Fleming, trustee of Make nds Count, said: ldquoWe are completely blown away by the generosity of Leighrsquos friends and family at such a desperately sad time.ldquoTo raise such a huge amount of money in such a short period of time is a clear testament to how loved and respected a person Leigh was. The funds raised will continue to support our work in funding research into secondary breast cancer and to help families like Leighrsquos.The fundraising page, that has now raised pound, was set up by Prestonpansrsquo Lynda Reid, who said: ldquoI have known Leigh since we started Prestonpans Infant School in . As you grow up and leave school to start employment people tend to go their separate ways but, in our community, you may not see each other everyday but we still rally round in times of need.ldquoI decided to start the fundraiser to raise money for the Make nds Count charity in memory of Leigh after reading the article in last weekrsquos Courier.ldquoIt was a heart-breaking read and after seeing the comment that Leigh had wanted to raise money for the charity but never got around to it really hit me. Leigh touched so many peoplersquos lives over the years and this fundraiser has shown just how much people thought of her.ldquoWe have also had donations from people who didnrsquot know Leigh but were touched by the story. It is important that we highlight the great work that this charity has done for Leigh and will continue to do for others in the future.Leighrsquos funeral service takes place on Tuesday, at .am at Prestongrange Church, Prestonpans. Bright colours are welcome but no denims. To donate to the campaign, search Lynda Reid on Facebook.

title: time-get-smart-energy-greener-supply
story: So, what is it and where do smart meters fit in According to the National Grid, Britainrsquos reliance on cleaner energy sources will overtake fossil fuels this year. And Scotland is leading the way, with the Scottish government aiming for renewable sources to generate the equivalent of  per cent of Scotlandrsquos gross annual electricity consumption by .To allow us to use more renewable energy we need to upgrade our current system to a smarter energy network.This will ensure we make the most of the greener energy available and open the door to a more sustainable future.With the uptake of smart meters in homes around Great Britain will come a new, smarter system, which is a more flexible and decarbonised. Whatrsquos more, this system is central to the country reducing its CO emissions, whilst being more reliable, sustainable and cost-effective.The increased complexity of the system and the need to be able to flexibly match supply and demand means that digitalisation is an important part of the transition. Central to digitalisation is the accurate measurement of customer energy demands so the system can provide energy in the most efficient and costeffective way, and customers can accurately understand how they use energy. And that is where smart meters ndash available from your energy supplier at no extra cost - come in.Simply put, smart meters will make Britainrsquos energy grid, and energy system, smarter. This is because the data that they are able to generate allows our energy network to understand how much energy is being used, when and where across Great Britain. The system will also be able to draw on more local and renewable sources of energy.Our electricity needs are predicted to double by , so we have to upgrade our outdated energy grid. Just by having a smart meter in your home, yoursquoll be helping the grid to better anticipate demand and reduce waste, readying it to meet the demands of the future.For more information visitsmartenergyGB.orgThe HeraldrsquosClimate for Changeinitiative supports efforts being made by the ScottishGovernmentwith key organisations and campaign partners. Throughout the year we will provide a forum in The Herald newspaper, online at herald.scotland and inBusinessHQ magazine, covering news and signicant developments in this increasingly crucial area.If you are interested in contributing editorially or interestedin becoming aClimate for Changepartner,please contactStephen McTaggarton  or emailstephen.mctaggart@heraldandtimes

title: tim-39-s-tales-holding-bucket
story: SO THOSE who have children of school age are back to the term-time routine. I think for many parents who have childcare challenges,there can be a real sense of relief as the summer holidays end, and to some extent I feel that myself.The pressure to fill six weeks with entertainment and activities, and go on holiday, can be immense, especially on a tight budget. For some children too, the holidays can be a dficult time and school can offer them ato some familiar routine.However, I remember the impending dread I felt when I was a child in the final days of the summer holidays. I hated the back to school adverts on TV as they heralded the end of free days playing on the rocks at the Pans shore, and of loosely defined bedtimes.So I was glad that our youngest daughter Skye was looking forward to school as she enters P. She met friends she hadnrsquot seen in weeks this morning and smiled as she said hello to George the lollipop man.She seemed slightly anxious as she waited in line in a new place, but the friendly manner of her new teacher visibly lted her mood and she went in with a smile, unknowingly tracing my childhood footsteps and those of her big sister.But then as I walked home, I was suddenly overwhelmed with anxieties: money worries, work worries, deadlines, bills etc. It seemed asduring the holiday period I had consciously decided to put such thoughts aside, to just enjoy the family time. Now was the pay back, we had ed to lsquorealityrsquo.But then I suddenly remembered a tale a fellow storyteller had told me many years ago. It just popped into my head and it spoke to me as I wandered back. And the truth in the story was the antidote I needed in that moment. And so I will share it with you in case you may one day find you need it:There was once a weaver who was weighed down with worries. He had so many things to do, so many responsibilities he looked into the future with dread. His worries kept him awake at night, which of course made his worrying worse during the next day. It was a vicious cycle.Then one day, he was sitting at his loom working and his worries got in the way. He couldnrsquot concentrate and he made mistake after mistake. He cursed and this was heard by an auld guidewe who happened to be passing by his window.ldquoFir whit reason dae ye curse at yer loom son, is there nae joy in yer work  she asked.The weaver looked up, feeling ashamed: ldquoIrsquom sair sorry fir ma words. Itrsquos just that as I work I think aboot orsquo ma troubles.The old woman nodded in understanding. She knew about troubles herself.ldquoAye, she said with an understanding nod, ldquotroubles can fair get ye doon.Then she paused and thought for a moment. She could see in the weaverrsquos face that he was riddled with anxieties.ldquoCan I show ye something that will tak ye awa frae yer work fir only a few minutes The weaver was happy to have a break so he left his loom and came outside.ldquoDae ye hae a bucket  asked the guidewe.ldquoA bucket ldquoAye a bucket, tae put some water in, she explained.The weaver fetched his bucket, wondering what the old woman was going to do with it.She took it to the well and filled it with a little water.ldquoNoo son, I dinnae kenthis will be tae heavy fir ye tae hold up.The weaver laughed: ldquoOrsquo course itrsquos no too heavy, fir ye only put a wee drop orsquo water in it.So the woman asked him to prove this by holding up the bucket with arms outstretched. The weaver had strong arms because of his work and held the bucket before him without any effort.ldquoAh, said the guidewe, ldquosae itrsquos nae tae heavy.ldquoIt isnae heavy at arsquo, replied the weaver.The old woman smiled: ldquoIn that case, keep haudin it afore ye like that fir  minutes. He wondered why she was asking him to do this, andshe was just trying to make a fool of him. But he was also intrigued and knew her to be an honest old soul, and so he did as she asked.After a few minutes of holding the bucket in front of him, it began to feel much heavier. After five minutes, his arms began to ache and soon they began to shake. The pain began to spread to his back as he desperately tried to keep the bucket in position.ldquoIs  minutes no over yet  asked the weaver desperately.ldquoIf the bucket is now tae heavy fir ye, put it doon son.He was reluctant to admit that the bucket was now too heavy to hold and so put it down.ldquoThe water got heavier son, didnrsquot it ldquoThe water wasnae heavier, protested the weaver, ldquoye just made me hold the bucket for tae lang.ldquoSae the water did get heavier, no in itself, but for you!The weaver looked confused and the guidewe continued.ldquoWater can get heavierye haud it ower lang afore ye, evenitrsquos just a wee drop. Yer worries are like that water, son. I am sure that they are many but ye mak them much heavierye try tae haud them in yer thochts arsquo the time.She smiled at him: ldquoTry an put the bucket doon as often as ye can,ye ken whit I mean. Dinnae mak it heavier than needs be. When ye need tae, haud it, but no arsquo the time.ldquoIn fact, she added while raising a pointed finger, ldquohauding it arsquo the time gies ye pain and paralyses ye. Yersquoll hae nae ability left tae empty the bucket.And so the old woman wandered off, leaving her words with the weaver. He looked down at the bucket. He lted it again and held it in front of him. It wasnrsquot as heavy now as before, but still had the same amount of water in it. She was right, water can get heavieryou hold it for longer, even though itrsquos the same weight.He chuckled to himself and watched the woman as she waddled down the street.ldquoThank ye! he called out.He ed to his loom. This time he whistled and sang as he worked. He enjoyed his creation and made no mistakes, for he had put his bucket of worries down for a while.Later they would still be there, but they might seem lighter and easier to manage now that they had stopped paralysing him with anxiety.And so that was the story. And as I arrived home, I realised that although I needed to deal with lots of things, I wasnrsquot going to give my worries more weight by holding them constantly in my thoughts.Itrsquos really important to put your bucket down every now and then, and that can make it easier to empty as well.

title: letter-railway-isn-39-t-perfect-39-s-better-driving
story: Sure, things may go awry from time to time ndash staff shortages, mechanical breakdowns, weather, etc, stuff happens, although after six months trialling the service, not once has there been a cancellation of a service I had been planning to use, whilst occasional delays can be measured, in frequency and duration, on the fingers of one hand.Having come somewhat late to the party, put off driving into Edinburgh most days due to seemingly never-ending roadworks, traffic congestion and exorbitant parking charges in the Capital, I have found the ScotRail service between North Berwick and Edinburgh to have been iniably punctual, reliable, clean, efficient and relatively inexpensive.Travelling between Longniddry and Edinburgh by train is clearly not only the most environmentally sustainable solution but also the most time-efficient ndash  minutes compared to anything up to an hour by car ndash and cost-effective, costing just pound.with a senior railcard, pound. without.Making use of the freeparking at Longniddry is a no-brainer, whilst parking in Edinburgh city centre currently costs pound. per hour ndash assuming a space can be found ndash meaning a two-hour sojourn in the Capital, including fuel can cost upwards of pound, four times more expensive than taking the train.Complete with a takeaway coffee from the adjacentFilling Station cafe, a complimentary copy of thenewspaper, free on-board wi-fi and unfailingly helpful, professional staff, whatrsquos not to like about the hourly service to and from Edinburgh Two minor gripes can occasionally detract somewhat from the experience: first, the frequency with which tickets are neither checked nor sold onboard, or on exiting Waverley station on arrival, creating the potential for fare-dodging.And, secondly, the apparent penchant for a signicant minority of adolescents, the majority of them, it would appear, girls, to sit with their feet up on the seat opposite, a common practice never seemingly challenged by onboard ScotRail staff, begging the question, would their parents let them get away with wearing outdoor shoes on the sofa at home However, despite these minor grumbles, from here on in, I plan to continue to avoid the road traffic pain, let the train take the strain and proffer a rare vote of confidence for Scotlandrsquos railway.Mike WilsonLochhill Farm CottagesLongniddry

title: say-future-dunbar-39-s-20mph-speed-limit
story: A consultation ndash both online and through leaflets being posted through doors ndash is under way to seethe public want the reduced speed limit to remain in place.The speed limit on roads north of the East Coast Mainline was dropped from mph last summer, with an -month trial starting.That trial is due to end in late September and the council could look to make the lower speed limit permanent.However, feedback from members of the public on the change has been mixed, with a number questioning its effectiveness.George Robertson, from the townrsquos community council, stressed the consultation needed to be ldquothorough.He said: ldquoThe feedback has been very mixed some are in favour and quite a few are opposed.ldquoI think where we are at the moment is we have already talked as part of the community council to East Lothian Council to convince them that they need to do a comprehensive survey of local opinion in order to determine the way ahead.The townrsquos community council has been heavily involved in discussions surrounding the reduced speed limit in the town.Mr Robertson said original discussions looked at the speed limit on residential streets, such as Countess Road, being reduced to mph.At that time, the plan was for the greater speed limit ndash mph ndash to remain in place on, at least, sections of the main arterial routes, such as Belhaven Road, but they had their speed limit lowered too.Fellow community councillor Herbert Coutts has been firmly behind the calls for the reduced speed limit.He said: ldquoMy feeling is that the speed trial has been a useful exercise and that a considerable number of people have been law abiding and have observed the mph speed limit or near to it.A council spokeswoman confirmed that the consultation would focus mainly on whether the current streets covered by the limits should be made permanent or,not, what alternative would be preferred ndash space is also available to make suggestions of both removing streets or indeed adding streets.There is also the opportunity to add comments regarding speed limits in Hallhill, south of the railway line, which also has a near-blanket mph limit which is already permanent.Responses can be submitted online, while , leaflets will be posted through the doors of homes in Dunbar and West Barns.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe introduction of the temporary mph limits was in response to community requests and the temporary traffic order gives an opportunity to assess whether itrsquos an option to be made permanent.ldquoThe consultation will seek the views not only of drivers but other road users and pedestrians. and we hope both residents and local businesses will take the opportunity to respond.The consultation is at east lothianconsultations infrastructure dunbar-north-mph-speed-limit

title: fringe-sea-2019-hailed-great-success
story: Sell-out signs outside the Spiegeltents were proof of the erse interests of both residents and visitors to North Berwick for this yearrsquos festival, which came to a close on Sunday.Political talks from former Prime Minister Gordon Brown and former Secretary of State for Scotland David Mundell created a lot of attention comedy from Fred MacAulay, Simon Evans, Janey Godley, Reginald D Hunter and Jamie MacDonald produced a lot of laughs and music from all genres brought crowds along to listen and dance.Family shows, as ever, were a huge hit, seeing toddlers throw shapes at the Monski Mouse Baby Disco Dancehall, to Dr Ben Garrod enthralling them all with his incredible knowledge of dinosaurs.Inspirational women talked about their lives and influences, with one having the audience in tears as she reminisced about what had changed her le.When the sun shone, people gathered at the harbourside at the Fringe by the Sea venue, soaking up the atmosphere and eating from the selection of top-quality food that North Berwick restaurants and cafes had to offer. From pizza to mussels and ice cream, not to mention The Ship Inn bar, it proved to be an lsquoinrsquo place to hang out.On Friday, Scottish explorer Mollie Hughes had the festival crew in stitches as they prepared the stage during one of the most torrential bouts of rain. Undaunted by the lashing rain, she said: ldquoThis is worse than the top of Mount Everest.Niall Middleton, co-director of Fringe by the Sea, said: ldquoThis has been an outstanding year. The feedback from both audiences and participants has been incredible as they have all enjoyed being part of the festival.ldquoWe couldnrsquot have done it without our funders, sponsors and volunteers.ldquoSo roll on  as we look forward to seeing North Berwick host what we think is the best festival around.

title: musselburgh-sisters-debuting-edinburgh-festival-fringe
story: Elaine and Katrina Hunter will stage a plethora of musical styles at their new show lsquoStar Inspirationsrsquo at Greenside @ Infirmary Street,  Infirmary Street, Forest Theatre, Venue , from this Monday to next Saturday .They will be joined by other cast members from Elainersquos Leith-based singing and performance coaching studio Vox Stars to celebrate aspiring singers.The sisters, who were born and bred in the Honest Toun at Newhailes, where they still live, come from a long line of fisherfolk.Their great grandmother Elizabeth lsquoBettyrsquo Millar was known as the last creel-carrying fishwe in Scotland and went on to be awarded a British Empire Medal.Elaine, , whose stage name is Lainey Vox, said: ldquoWe grew up on the same street as our great grandmother and she encouraged our performing arts ventures, clapping and waving her hankie to our living room performances on top of her wee box.ldquoShe also loved nothing more than a chat about handbags and fashion over their Friday night fish dinners. I think this may have kickstarted my love for costumes.Their grandmother Patricia Millar owned her own fish van called MG for nearly  years and these strong female family members inspired Elaine to open her own business Vox Stars in .They have also inspired the Fringe show which features a tribute to women who have influenced the Vox Starsrsquo vocalists who, in turn, will perform their own rendition of the Eurythmics hit Sisters Are Doing It For Themselves at the show.Elaine said that she and her sister Katrina, , had always shared a love of performing arts, attending Morag Alexanderrsquos School of Dance in Musselburgh as young girls.At the age of just two, Elaine took part in her first performance at The Brunton, during which she was supposed to dance as a sheep to Baa Baa Black Sheep but she began to rebel and sing instead, to rave reviews.Elaine can also been seen in old family film footage rocking to her favourite band Queen and she began teaching herself to sing and perform while watching the bandrsquos frontman Freddie Mercury in action.The sisters went through many challenges in their childhood, facing bullying over their dyslexic dficulties.Freddie Mercuryrsquos story and music, along withe encouragement from their family, inspired both sisters to celebrate their dferences and gave them the determination to succeed.Aiming to perform to a wider audience, Elaine began to attend lessons in Edinburgh as a teenager, progressing on to performances in a iety of social clubs and then became a finalist at Edinburghrsquos Got Talent.She graduated with a first-class honours degree in popular music and performance from Perth College, University of the Highlands and Islands.Katrina, who works in retail and is a key part of the Vox Starsrsquo team, attained a degree in psychology from Musselburgh-based Queen Margaret University.Star Inspirations will feature classic hits by Queen and ABBA and modern favourites by Beyonceacute and Ed Sheeran, as well as My Chemical Romance and Panic At The Disco. A Disney medley is also on the programme.Elaine said: ldquoThis opportunity to grace the awesome Fringe  has been given to children who are just starting their singing journey and adults who are rekindling their passion for voice.The hour-long show will get under way at .pm, with tickets, priced pound , available from the box office on    or booking website tickets.edfringe

title: auction-promises-held-haddington-church
story: A major renovation of the lighting inside St Maryrsquos Parish Church was completed earlier this summer, with attention now turning to a kitchen.An Auction of Promises takes place in the church this evening , with funds raised at the event going to the new kitchen, which would enable the church to better serve the many iniduals and groups that use the historic building, off Sidegate.As well as an opportunity to go along and admire the new lighting, the evening will also be a chance to meet and chat with many of the folk who work to keep the church at the heart of its community, and its new minister, the Rev Alison McDonald.There will be music throughout the evening, with cheese and biscuits provided.All are welcome to lsquobring their own bottlersquo, enjoy the surroundings and consider bidding for one of the many items on the list.A spokeswoman for the church said: ldquoThe congregation has been overwhelmed with the generosity shown towards its latest fundraising effort.ldquoOver  lots are available, including a private tour of Bonhamsrsquo Scottish art sale, a week at a self-catering cottage in Wester Ross, two separate private whisky tastings by Whisky Belle and Berry Brothers and Rudd , afternoon tea at the Maitlandfield House Hotel and a flight in a microlight.ldquoSuccessful bidders can also have their Christmas cards written and addressed, enjoy home title: old-bus-turned-mobile-music-food-hairdressing-facility
story: Tranent-based social enterprise Heavy Sound CIC has commandeered an old bus and, after collaborating with the Scottish Prison Serviceand Police Scotlandrsquos Violence Reduction Unit , the bus will be transformed into a portable community service complete with music production equipment, a food prep kitchen and a small hairdressing space.Jordan Butler, founder of Heavy Sound, said: ldquoThe bus is a long-standing idea of my colleague Linda [Bendle] and it really captures the spirit of what we try and do here at Heavy Sound, which is use music to create aims and aspirations through youth work.The bus is being converted by HMP Edinburgh ndash more commonly known as Saughton Prison ndash which will allow prisoners to receive accreditation for working on it.Jordan added: ldquoThe men and women who are working on the bus are gaining new skills that will help them in the world of work when they get out, which is fantastic.ldquoThe plan is that the bus is completed by the end of the month and is up and running and in use by mid-September.The bus will also work with local services and national services including Shelter, Barnardorsquos, Edinburgh Aid and Abet and the homeless booking service, in order to increase support.Jordan added: ldquoEventhe bus doesnrsquot last for ever, or there are areas we canrsquot get back to quickly, it will help identy key activities that are worth keeping for each place.ldquoIf something we do goes down really well and is really successful, then evenwe donrsquot supply it, there will be some other group that can supply it and know that it will work well.ldquoWe have had so much support from the council to local charities who are getting involved. Itrsquos really exciting!The Heavy Sound base is situated at  High Street, Tranent.

title: noel-ferry-future-proofing-assets
story: In addition to the anxiety about how children or other family members might be affected, the future can seem very forbiddingone or both partnerrsquos share of the joint property, pensions and savings are in dispute ndashat one of the most harrowing times of anyonersquos le.Noel Ferry, a partner at legal firm Turcan Connell and a specialist in family law, believes that with sound legal advice that allows a couple to go into marriage or cohabitation with their eyes wide open and aware of the potential pitfalls, the trauma of such events can be substantially ameliorated.One of the first facts to establish when a client enquires about separation or orce, he says, is whether they are married, in a civil partnership or cohabiting. ldquoThere is still a dference in law as to how their situation is taken into account when deciding how to ide the couplersquos assets and the results can be quite dferent eventhey have been living together for some time, he explains.Important dferencesldquoWhile itrsquos common for people to assume that the same rules apply, they donrsquot the law has obviously improved the situation for cohabiting couples and given them more rights but they do not mimic those for married couples.These new rights were established by the Family Law Scotland Act  and whereas a spouse can claim a capital sum, maintenance payments, a transfer of property or a share of their husband or wersquos pension, cohabitees are restricted to claiming a capital sum to redress any economic advantage disadvantage.First StepsldquoIn either case, the first thing I do is have a discussion with the client to explore the possibility of resolving their situation without separation: do they really need to separate ndashor would they like assistance before they take that serious step, says Ferry.ldquoIf so, we can put them in touch with a family therapist or relationship counsellorthey havenrsquot yet reached the stage of beginning proceedings.Consider the alternative approachThe second, important piece of advice is that that there are alternative resolution methods available. The procedure for iding matrimonial property, which is any money and other assets owned jointly or inidually is that it is to be ided fairly, which may not simply mean equally. If the situation has to be resolved in court that can result in a decision that is far from satisfactory to one ndashor both ndashof the partners.ldquoItrsquos important that we advise clients about the fact that Alternative Dispute Resolution is available. These situations emphatically donrsquot involve an inevitable progress to court ndashwhich should be regarded as very much the last resort, he says.In fact, some % or more of cases are now dealt with through negotiation rather than a court order that determines the ision of assets. People who proceed to court, says Ferry almost inevitably have an urgent issue such as suffering from a serious shortage of money or protection issues resulting from circumstances of domestic abuse.The alternative routes principally involve collaboration or mediation. Mediation, involves an independent mediator guiding the parties toward a solution. The mediator does not usually give them legal advice as to their entitlements though in assisted mediation both parties have their solicitors in the background .ldquoThat is an option that sometimes works out well ndash but many people are looking for veriable answers, and this can be achieved through the collaborative approach which I find is generally a better way to resolve disagreements.Ferry, a trained collaborative lawyer, believes this route is best to minimise conflict and secure financial choices ndashwhile also, importantly, ensuring the best future for the children. He explains that collaborative law involves the parties and their advisers in four-way meetings with discussions around the table, in private and without the delay of correspondence and court proceedings. And this, he says helps to avoid subsequent, and potentially costly, misunderstandings.The problem with pensionsPensions, for example, can become very contentious. ldquoIn our experience pensions are frequently overlooked by clients when considering orce settlements. However, the value of the pensions built up during the marriage or civil partnership is taken into account and can be substantial. Our clientsrsquo settlements often involve pension sharing agreements.ldquoHowever, pensions can be extremely complicated ndashnot only in terms of valuing them and iding them but itrsquos also important to get the best advice on which pensions should be shared and which should not. Some have more benefits attached to them than others. For example, there may be spousersquos benefits attached to them which may be very valuable.In addition, he adds, there are ious types of pensions such as Self Invested Personal Pensionswhich can be convoluted when dealing with them in orce cases as sometimes these can involve multiple underlying property and other assets contained in the pension which may need to be valued too.ldquoYou need to take advice not only about its value at the date of separation but also its type of pension and current value. A failure to identy pension interests or to correctly apportion the value of a pension may have dramatic long-term implications for either spouse and there is a strict timescale involved after orce for implementing the pension share.Business assetsFerry says that clients also need advice about business assets and shareholdings, as to what constitutes matrimonial property as these can, inadvertently, be converted into matrimonial property in the course of, for example, restructuring a company that was founded or bought before marriage.ldquoShareholdings that may be worth several millions can be transferred into the joint matrimonial pot and that possibility is not often considered by the accountant or tax advisor involved, he says.These are just a few of the issues to be considered but despite the obvious vexations that separation and orce involve, Ferry believes in confronting them in a positive, proactive way. The Family LawAct of  was well thought out and is quite flexible, providing for the needs of inidual cases, he says.Divorce, he adds, need not end up in long, drawn out court proceedings. ldquoWhether via a pre-nuptial agreement or a collaborative resolution, with good legal advice parties can deal with separation and orce in way that achieves the solution that works best for them both.Noel specialises in all areas of family law but is particularly noted for acting in high value cases for high net worth iniduals, for example, celebrities, sports personalities, entrepreneurs, business owners, directors, professionals and executives. Noel has successively been ranked by the Legal  for his experience in high net worth orces, prenuptial agreements and child relocation cases and has been described as providing "outstanding service", being "absolutely committed to the case" and having "exemplary" knowledge.Noel has extensive experience as a litigator having regularly appeared in both civil and criminal court cases before specialising in family law cases since . Noel has considerable expertise in negotiating financial settlements and regularly drafts complex separation agreements as well as pre-nuptial and cohabitation agreements. Noel has acted for many high profile clients and has been involved in many prominent orce cases in the Court of Session and Sherf courts. Noel has also acted in several international child relocation cases. Noel has also acted for clients with complex family trusts as well as dficult cohabitation claims on separation and death under the Family LawAct . Noel has assisted in many professional negligence cases involving family lawyers and has been asked for his expert opinion on several cases of potential negligence.Noel Ferry, Partner at Turcan ConnellTel:       Web:www.turcanconnell

title: new-art-display-north-berwick-focuses-dementia
story: Residents of Fidra Nursing Home alongside pARTicipate art group have collaborated to give the cabins a new lease of le.The display was the idea of Fidrarsquos activities coordinator Clare Overton, who wanted to commemorate Dementia Awareness Week by making lsquoForget-me-Notsrsquo, the symbol of Dementia Friendly North Berwick.Clare began collecting the materials for her art project and realised that the bottom of fizzy drinks bottles made the perfect flower shape.The residents painted the bottom of the bottle and then printed them onto paper.Clare said: ldquoMany of our residents were creative before I met them and it was a pleasure to see them rediscovering their talents and abilities. For others it was a new experience, but all found a sense of achievement.ldquoWe took several of them to see their work completed and they were all so proud.Clare approached Dementia Friendly North Berwick about her project.The group pointed her in the direction of Geraldine Prince from pARTicipate art group, who organised an artist to install the piece in one of the phone cabin micro-museums on North Berwick High Street.It was Julia Zeller-Jacques who accepted the challenge of installing the display.Julia said: ldquoI found the ideas moving and also stimulating. I wanted ndash literally ndash to reflect the experience of dementia sufferers so it would have an impact on the wider public.ldquoI decided to line the telephone booths with mirrors both to maximise the impact and also to allow anyone looking at the artworks to see themselves reflected in the space.ldquoDementia can affect anyone and anyone can take an interest and give someone living with dementia the patience and respect the need.Geraldine, arts activities coordinator at pARTicipate, said: ldquoPeople are liking it. It is exactly a year since we got permission from the council to take the cabins and give them a makeover.ldquoThey are going to achieve their full potential. I even cleaned the cabins and gave them their first coat of paint.ldquoWe have received a iety of grants, funds and sponsorships which has allowed us to make this possible and enable people who might not think of themselves as artists to make something beautul and have it displayed in the town.ldquoIt is something beautul coming from the community, for the community.On seeing her work displayed, Frances Dinwoodie, Fidra resident, said: ldquoI didnrsquot think that arts and crafts was my cup of tea but once I started painting I really did enjoy it and when I saw the display I thought it looked so fantastic I actually felt like crying.

title: decision-due-bid-build-homes-next-historic-tenterfield-house
story: East Lothian Council planners have rejected two applications to build houses next to Tenterfield House in Haddington.The category-B listed house dates back to the th century and was once home to Sir Stuart Donaldson, who served as Premier in .Although his premiership was short and he resigned after two months and  days, he gave the house name to the town of Tenterfield, where he lived, and through that to the Tenterfield Oration ndash a speech which led to the federation of Australia.Sir Stuartrsquos Haddington home would go on to be a Christie Home for Orphans until it was taken over by the local authority.It closed in  and was converted into flats.The housing plans are for land which had previously been part of the house gardens which have been subided.KRA has applied for planning permission to build two homes on one part of the land and a single house next door to them.Both applications have previously been rejected by the councilrsquos planning officers.Local objectors submitted concerns which ranged from the impact on a colony of bats which live in Tenterfield House to concerns about losing mature trees and a loss of privacy.Planning officers said claims by the applicant that the site did not form any part of recreational amenity of the area demonstrated they had ldquofailed to understand that the grassed open area is a valuable amenity asset within the area, depicting the parkland character and the feeling of openness within the treed landscape.Planning officers also raised concerns about the impact on the wider Haddington conservation area and another listed building Old Bank House.The applicant is appealing their decision, insisting that the impact on the conservation area and setting of the listed buildings is ldquominor and would in the long term prove beneficial.The councilrsquos Local Review Body will discuss the appeal at a meeting on Thursday.

title: haddington-shop-owner-wins-dream-holiday-maldives
story: Teresa Sear, along with husband Dan and children Abi and Beth, are getting ready to swap Haddington for a fortnight in the Males after winning a competition.Teresa, who has owned greetings card and gt shop Expressions on the townrsquos High Street for about five years, told the Courier that the family could not wait until the holiday in October.She said: ldquoIt is somewhere that is totally dferent to where you would usually go.ldquoIt is so dferent it will be a real experience with snorkelling, seeing sharks, stingrays and all kinds of fish.The amazing holiday to the island nation came about after Teresa entered a competition through her work.All independent stores that placed an order for Second Naturersquos new products by the end of January were entered into a holiday prize draw.The top prize was a pound, holiday and Teresa, who lives in Haddington, was shocked when she received a phone call to confirm that her name had been pulled out of a hat and she was the lucky winner.Teresa and Dan, both , enjoyed their honeymoon in the tropical Indian Ocean country, off the coast of Sri Lanka,  years ago.The couple will fly out with -year-old Abi and Beth, , from Glasgow in October.A stop-off in Dubai is followed by a flight to the Males before a sea plane transfer to the island.Teresa said: ldquoWe are just back from a holiday in Devon and that was to be the main summer holiday this year.ldquoWe found out we would be going on this amazing holiday and Devon felt really boring in comparison and we just kept thinking about the Males.ldquoThe girls are just so happy.

title: golfers-tee-riffic-effort-raise-nearly-10-000-leuchie-house
story: The four golfers who took part in the challenge played  holes of golf in one day in aid of the respite care centre, located near North Berwick.Jason Preston, one of the golfers, said: ldquoI came across Leuchie House when their work was showcased at the Scottish Open last year and became involved again when my neighbour, Mark, became the new CEO six months ago.ldquoAfter recently moving here, East Lothian, and golf in general, has brought great pleasure to my family.ldquoSo, itrsquos been great that friends from Renaissance, the town and further afieldcould support the four of us in our -hole challenge this year, to raise money for this national charity based on our doorstep.The other golfers who took part alongside Jason were Gordon Forbes, Marc Teague and Rob Aberdein.Leuchie House offers short breaks for people suffering from long-term neurological conditions, such as multiple sclerosis, motor neurone disease, cerebral palsy and Parkinsonrsquos.The centre, which is an independent charity, also provides respite for carers from their day-to-day caring responsibilities.Mark Bevan, Leuchie Housersquos Chef executive, said: ldquoLocal people like Jason and the boys are huge supporters of Leuchie ndash we just could not provide the service we offer to people from across Scotland without their generous support.ldquoWe have to raise over poundm a year to just stand still and every donation makes a signicant dference to the urgent need of those who use Leuchie House.ldquoGolf has been a good friend to us and we look forward to other courses taking up the -hole challenge next year.Donations can be made by texting FORE to  to donate pound.

title: plans-lodged-haddington-house-refurbishment
story: Plans for a full refurbishment of Haddington House have been drawn up by The Lamp of Lothian Trust.Works on the Category A listed building, on the townrsquos Sidegate, include new heating, kitchens and toilets.The building dates back to the th century, with ious additions having been added in later years.The Lamp of Lothian Trust restored Haddington House in  and is now looking to carry out further work, which would see the sub-ision of one room, with a car park barrier put in place outside.Lamp of Lothian confirmed the plans to revamp the building at the beginning of June.Now the proposals have been validated by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, which allows members of the public to have their say.It is expected the scheme, which would cost a six-figure sum, would provide office space over three floors.When the proposals to turn the building into a multi-let office were first revealed, Jenny Harper, vice-chairman of the Lamp of Lothian Board of Trustees, highlighted the importance of the building.She said: ldquoHaddington House is the jewel in the Lamp of Lothianrsquos crown and our principle revenue-producing asset, which allows us to provide a range of free facilities to the local community.ldquoThe investment we are making in Haddington House will future-proof the building and we are looking forward to welcoming new tenants later in the year.

title: 39-s-knockout-event-coming-leuchie-house
story: The event takes place between pm and pm on Leuchiersquos own grounds near North Berwick.The inflatable obstacle course aims to unleash participantsrsquo inner child and be a real test of strength, agility, speed and teamwork.Teams of between six and  can take part but bookings must be made in advance.The cost of entering a team is pound and forms can be obtained by emailing lbambridge@leuchiehouse.org.ukRegistration for the event begins at pm on the day.The Itrsquos a Knockout arena will be open to the public, with residents invited to go along, watch and enjoy the fun.There will be games for children, a foodie village, street traders, music and face painting also on offer.Mark Bevan, Leuchie chief executive, said: ldquoFundraising is absolutely crucial to Leuchie House and wersquore delighted to be hosting such an exciting event to help with our fundraising efforts.ldquoWe have to raise over pound million a year to just stand still and every donation makes a signicant dference to the urgent need of those who visit, helping us to provide quality respite to our guests and their carers.ldquoWe are hugely grateful to sponsors Charles River who have made the event possible and we look forward to a fantastic day here at Leuchie.For more information, visit Leuchie Housersquos website at leuchiehouse.org.uk get-involved knockout

title: midfielder-crutches-tranent-juniors-tie-hibs-abandoned
story: The Hibees XI were leading - at Foresters Park on Tuesday evening with five minutes left when Ben was badly hurt in a challenge with visiting defender Kos Sadiki.The referee abandoned the tie, with Ben from Tranent, taken to hospital for a scan which revealed he had damaged tendons in his ankle, following suggestions that he had broken his leg.Ben spoke to the Courier about the injury and said his ankle had gone into ldquoa weird position after the tackle.He added: ldquoI got pins and needles into my knee and I tried to stand up because I had got a fright.ldquoI thought it was broken and stood up but could not put any weight on it and just fell to the floor. That is when the pain went straight up my leg.ldquoThere were about five minutes left and they were going to take me off. I could not stand up because of the pain shooting up my leg and they brought on the stretcher.ldquoThe referee then decided to call it a day.However, that was just the start of an eventful night for Ben who said: ldquoThey tried to phone an ambulance but since my leg was not bleeding and the bone was not sticking out of my leg they could not send one. I went up to the hospital in my managerrsquos [Calvin Shand] van because itrsquos easier to get in and out of a van than a car.The -year-old midfielder had an x-ray on his right ankle at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh before being allowed to go home at .am yesterday .He was pleased to say there was no fracture or ligament damage and he was likely to spend just over a month on the sidelines.The joiner is currently on crutches and taking antibiotics and has taken the rest of the week off due to the injury.Jamie Gullan, who spent time on loan with Raith Rovers last term, scored twice for the Hibs side in East Lothian.Ben, who played for the Easter Road side from under- to under- level, said: ldquoHibs are full-time and they are really good, fit young boys. We were doing well but we could not really test the goalkeeper as much as we wanted to do. They have got fresh legs and they scored two goals but we never really tested the goalkeeper as much as we wanted.Tranent boss Calvin Shand was pleased it was not as serious an injury as first feared.He said: ldquoI think, at the time, we feared the worst. It looked a sore one and with him getting taken to hospital it was feared it could be long term.ldquoBut, it is not broken, which is a good thing and we will need to reassess it in a couple of days when the swelling goes down.ldquoIrsquom really disappointed for Ben, who has come back off holiday, back to fitness and had a good run of form.ldquoHe is a massive player for us and we are disappointed for us as a club but more for Ben as a player.

title: musselburgh-museum-closed-following-ceiling-leak
story: A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoMusselburgh Museum is operated by Musselburgh Museum and Heritage Group in partnership with the council.ldquoUnfortunately in the recent bad weather there was a leak from the ceiling.ldquoThe leak has only affected the office and corridor area ndash the museum and the exhibits have not been damaged.ldquoAs the building owners, the council is now organising repairs through our property maintenance team and we will ensure the work is carried out as quickly as possible to allow the museum to reopen as soon as possible.ldquoScaffolding has been erected outside the museum and repair works will shortly commence. The museum remains closed at this time and we will keep Musselburgh Museum and Heritage Group updated on this process and the timetable for the completion of works to enable them to re-open.She added that there was no immediate impact on future exhibition plans.The museum on High Street, which is run by volunteers, recently hosted an exhibition about the Musselburgh Festival.This finished on August  and artefacts are being ed to lenders.Prior to that, a display about Musselburgh Athletic Football Club through the years was also enjoyed by visitors.

title: man-brandished-screwdriver-incident
story: Craig Sheridan pulled out the makesht weapon at the townrsquos Longdykes Road in May.Sheridan, of Affleck Rise, also destroyed property belonging to another when he removed a wooden  on a garden shed at a property at nearby Middleshot Square.Sheridan, , admitted his guilt to both offences during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Tuesday.Sherf Adrian Cottam deferred sentence till next month for the preparation of background reports.Sheridan admitted wilfully damaging property belonging to another at an address at Middleshot Square, Prestonpans, on May .He also pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing, acting aggressively and brandishing a screwdriver at an address at Longdykes Road, Prestonpans, on the same date.

title: tim-39-s-tales-side-sunset
story: THE Boat Shore at Cockenzie is a magical place: a small natural cove, embraced by ancient rocks and a beach seeped in the history of the local community.Legend tells us that the name Cockenzie is derived from Cul Cionnich, meaning Cove of Kenneth in Gaelic.St Kenneth was a Celtic saint and a follower of St Columba. His missionary work took him all over Scotland, including the coastline of the Forth. It is said his arrival at this small natural harbour gave the place its name.Last weekend, artist Andrew Crummy, who lives in the village, organised three lsquosunset eveningsrsquo at the Boat Shore. Local musicians, singers, artists and actors gathered on the beach with an audience of fellow locals to share the sunset.I sadly couldnrsquot attend the first two but was able to make the last evening with some of my children. It was a wonderful mix of music and song, with a very funny short drama, and a setting sun as the backdrop.It was a poignant evening for myself, and I know for some others too a moment of reflection as well as coming together. I had planned to tell a tale about St Kenneth, but I changed my mind just before the event.Instead, I told a tale of a friendship between a tortoise and a butterfly and what sunsets meant to them. In story, anything is possible, and I made this tale to help ease someonersquos sadness in experiencing an ending.I was later askedI could share it, and so here is the story:There was once a tortoise who became friends with a butterfly. On the first day of their friendship, the tortoise invited the butterfly to sit with him on his favourite rock, to watch the sunset.However, Butterfly had no idea what a sunset was, and so when she saw the sun fall gradually from the sky she became concerned.ldquoWhatrsquos happening to the sun  she asked in a worried tone.ldquoItrsquos the sunset, said Tortoise, ldquoitrsquos when the sun goes down and ends the day.ldquoWhat, already! Thatrsquos it  asked Butterfly, horried. ldquoThis is just my first day being a butterfly and my days are over Tortoise smiled: ldquoNo my wee friend, itrsquos not all over. The sun will come back and there will be another day.But Butterfly remained anxious: ldquoHow can you be sure the sun will come back ldquoTrust me, I know. Irsquove seen many sunsets, said Tortoise. ldquoThe sun always comes back. Sometimes it takes longer than others, sometimes you canrsquot see the sun because of clouds, but it always s and makes another day.Butterfly was now reassured and so settled down to watch, as the sun dipped lower, painting the sky. She expected the sun to sizzle and the sea to steam when they touched each other, but of course that didnrsquot happen. The sun slid quietly below the horizon, leaving a trail of bright red and orange.ldquoThat was beautul, wasnrsquot it  Tortoise said.But Butterflyrsquos reply was unexpected: ldquoI think I donrsquot like sunsets very much.Tortoise curled up the wrinkles on his old face in surprise: ldquoWhy not, donrsquot you think it was spectacular, the way it painted the sky ldquoSuppose, but it was sad, really sad, said Butterfly.ldquoSad ldquoYes, because the sunset ends the day and thatrsquos sad. Endings are sad.Tortoise nodded in a way tortoises do when theyrsquore thinking: ldquoYes thatrsquos true, endings can be sad. But everything ends sooner or later. Nothing lasts forever.ldquoBut thatrsquos what I mean Tortoise, itrsquos so sad. I donrsquot want to sit and celebrate the end of something.Tortoise thought for a moment: ldquoAlthough endings can be sad, they also give meaning and value to our time. Without sunsets we would not treasure our days. Our le would become one long blah of sameness.ldquoA blah of sameness ldquoYes, my expression, smiled Tortoise proudly.ldquoBut thatrsquos easy for you to say, Tortoise, because you have more time than me, you will have more days.ldquoPerhaps, but that means your time is more precious than mine. And your sunsets are greater celebrations of your days.Butterfly thought about this. ldquoYou seem quite wise, Tortoise, she said, looking at her friend.ldquoYes, he replied immodestly, ldquoI do have that reputation. I suppose I have a lot of time to think, sitting on this rock.It began to get dark and colder.ldquoNow itrsquos time for our dreams. Soon there will be the sunrise, said Tortoise.ldquoSunrise  Is that when the sun s Tortoise nodded: ldquoYes, you see you donrsquot get a sunrise without a sunset. Although endings can be sad, they open the door to new beginnings. At the other side of a sunset there is a sunrise.Tortoise was indeed wise and Butterfly felt reassured by his wisdom.That summer, the two friends watched many sunsets together. They would share stories about their day as the sun went down. Then one evening, as flocks of geese were flying overhead, Butterfly spoke sadly.ldquoTortoise, I need to go. Itrsquos getting cold. Irsquom off to Africa. Do you think there are sunsets there ldquoIrsquom sure of it, replied Tortoise.ldquoI love sunsets now, said Butterfly. ldquoThey have shown me to treasure and celebrate my days. But I am sad this is our last one together.ldquoMe too, said Tortoise.The two friends sat together on their rock as the sunset commemorated their summer with a blaze of colour. Then they said goodbye.A new dawn now lay ahead for them both, for the end of one story is the beginning of another.And at the other side of a goodbye, there is a hello.

title: new-dunbar-grammar-school-head-boy-follows-mum-39-s-example
story: Thomas Leitch has been named head boy at Dunbar Grammar School, nearly  years after his mum, Karen Leitch, nee MacKay, was named as head girl.Thomas, , is joined by head girl Georgie Cross, with the duo looking to strengthen communication in the school and its eco credentials.Thomas, whose mum was head girl in -, said: ldquoBecoming head boy was always something I have been interested in.ldquoI would not say there was a pressure but I was pushed forward by my mum, who was head girl when she attended the school.ldquoI always wanted to give something back and I have enjoyed my six years and felt it was right for me.Georgie, also , previously planned to leave school and work for a year before looking to go on to university.She said: ldquoI made the decision to stay on towards the end of S.ldquoI was involved in the pupil council and the set-up already within the school.ldquoI made my decision to stay on and decided I was not a person to sit idle or who wanted it nice and easy I want to make a dference while I can, especially when I consider myself quite a confident person.Interested pupils put their names forward to become head boy or head girl and outlined what skills and attributes they possessed which they felt made them suitable.A hustings then took place within the school before speeches were given in front of senior pupils encouraging them to vote for them.An interview in front of Claire Slowther, headteacher at the school, and the outgoing head boy and head girl Ben Dorin and Hannah Dickson, followed before the results were revealed.Now the duo, along with deputes Ben Totten, Niamh Goldie, Alicia Lancaster and Emma Welsh, are looking forward to a busy year ahead.Thomas, who plays scrum-half for the schoolrsquos rugby team, told the Courier that communication had been at the heart of his manesto.He said: ldquoI really focused on communication within the school and making sure it is not just senior management and senior pupils who get a say.ldquoIt is everyone and I got that point across and set up drop-in sessions so we have always got younger pupils to get involved.Similarly, Georgie, of East Linton, was keen to strengthen the schoolrsquos eco profile.She added: ldquoOne issue I would push, which the school is doing, is to make the school as eco as possible.ldquoThere is a lot of buzz around climate change.Mrs Slowther said there was a strong list of candidates for the two roles.She added: ldquoBoth Thomas and Georgie stood out with their confidence, commitment to the school and a real sense of what they wanted to bring to the school.

title: pensioner-collided-schoolchildren-outside-musselburgh-grammar-school-avoids-driving-ban
story: Ian Steedman, , had just collected two children from outside Musselburgh Grammar School when he lost control of his car and ploughed into the three teenage pupils.Steedman, of Edinburgh Road, Tranent, believed that his brakes had failed, causing him to strike the schoolchildren, but tests carried out later on his Honda Civic showed no problems with the braking system.The grandad, who owns Bisset  Steedman in Tranent, later realised he had got his foot stuck under the brake pedal, causing him to lose control of the car last November.Steedman had initially pleaded guilty to dangerous driving last month but changed his plea after seeking legal advice.He appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court today , where he admitted an amended charge of careless driving by driving through a red light and colliding with three children and a vehicle at Musselburgh on November  last year.Fiscal depute Nicole Lavelle told the court that Steedman had collected a young relative and a friend from outside the school at about .pm before making his way onto the townrsquos Inveresk Road.Ms Lavelle said: ldquoAs the accused drove he became aware he could not stop his vehicle and he consequently drove onto the opposite carriageway to avoid two vehicles which had stopped at a red light.ldquoAs the -year-old boy passed halfway across the crossing, he was struck by the accusedlsquos vehicle, lting him up on to the bonnet."The vehicle also delivered a glancing blow to two others.ldquoThe accusedrsquos vehicle continued through the crossing and collided with the front near side of a car.The fiscal said two of the school pupils who were struck were  years old and the third was .Ms Lavelle added that the boy who landed on the bonnet of Steedmanrsquos car received a large gash to his upper leg after he ldquoended up between the two vehicles when they collided.Ms Lavelle said the boy then landed on the roadway and was rushed to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary for treatment he spent the night at the hospital.Steedman subsequently had his eyes tested by police officers and the court heard he had ldquoprovided a negative breath test following the incident.Defending solicitor Mary Moultrie said that her client had taken ldquoevasive action by pulling onto the opposite carriageway after realising he could not brake in time.Ms Moultrie added that Steedman ldquobelieved his brakes had failed at the time of the collision but afterwards realised he ldquomust have put his foot under the brake pedal.The lawyer said that Steedman had had a clean driving licence for the past  years and had been driving at a ldquovery low speed when he struck the three children.Ms Moultrie added: ldquoThis a genuine one-off, isolated incident that is very regrettable.Sherf Peter McCormack agreed and sentenced Steedman to a pound fine and placed six penalty points on his driving licence.
